H0.text: Which northern Duchies were questionable until the 1860s. Schleswig

H1.text: Which northern Duchies were questionable until the 1860s. Holstein

H2.text: Which northern Duchies were questionable until the 1860s. Saxe-Lauenburg

H3.text: Which northern Duchies were questionable until the 1860s. Lütt-Witt Moor

A4.text: The Second Schleswig War (1864) ended with the three duchies being governed jointly by Austria and Prussia. In 1866, they became a part of Prussia.

A5.text: Lauenburg was given to Prussia, while Austria administered Holstein, and Prussia administered Schleswig.

A6.text: In 1866, Saxe-Lauenburg joined the North German Confederation. However, its vote in the Bundesrat was counted along with those of Prussia.

A7.text: The violation of the primogeniture gave grounds for the estates to perceive the upcoming duke Francis II as illegitimate.

A8.text: The Schleswig–Holstein question was a complex set of diplomatic and other issues arising from the relations of two duchies, Schleswig and Holstein, to the Danish Crown, to the German Confederation, and to each other.

A9.text: The Schleswig–Holstein question gave rise to conflicts between major powers for much of the 19th century.
